column2: It's getting awful rough walking, said Dorothy, as they trudged along.
column3: It's getting awful rough walking, said Dorothy, as they trudged along.

column2: Button-Bright gave a deep sigh and said he was hungry.
column3: Button Bright gave a deep sigh and said he was hungry.

column2: Indeed, all were hungry, and thirsty, too; for they had eaten nothing but the apples since breakfast; so their steps lagged and they grew silent and weary.
column3: Indeed, all were hungry, and thirsty, too; for they had eaten nothing but the apples since breakfast; so their steps lagged and they grew silent and weary.

column2: At last they slowly passed over the crest of a barren hill and saw before them a line of green trees with a strip of grass at their feet.
column3: At last they slowly passed over the crest of a barren hill and saw before them a line of green trees with a strip of grass at their feet.

column2: An agreeable fragrance was wafted toward them.
column3: An agreeable fragrance was wafted toward them.

column2: Our travelers, hot and tired, ran forward on beholding this refreshing sight and were not long in coming to the trees.
column3: Our travelers, hot and tired, ran forward on beholding this refreshing sight and were not long in coming to the trees.

column2: Here they found a spring of pure bubbling water, around which the grass was full of wild strawberry plants, their pretty red berries ripe and ready to eat. Some of the trees bore yellow oranges and some russet pears, so the hungry adventurers suddenly found themselves provided with plenty to eat and to drink.
column3: Here they found a spring of pure bubbling water, around which the grass was full of wild strawberry plants, their pretty red berries ripe and ready to eat. Some of the trees bore yellow oranges and some russet pears, so the hungry adventurers suddenly found themselves provided with plenty to eat and to drink.

column2: They lost no time in picking the biggest strawberries and ripest oranges and soon had feasted to their hearts' content.
column3: They lost no time in picking the biggest strawberries and ripest oranges and soon had feasted to their hearts' content.

column2: Walking beyond the line of trees they saw before them a fearful, dismal desert, everywhere gray sand.
column3: Walking beyond the line of trees they saw before them a fearful, dismal desert, everywhere gray sand.

column2: At the edge of this awful waste was a large, white sign with black letters neatly painted upon it and the letters made these words:
column3: At the edge of this awful waste was a large, white sign with black letters neatly painted upon it and the letters made these words:

column2: ALL PERSONS ARE WARNED NOT TO VENTURE UPON THIS DESERT
column3: ALL PERSONS ARE WARNED NOT TO VENTURE UPON THIS DESERT

column2: For the Deadly Sands will Turn Any Living Flesh to Dust in an instant.
column3: For the Deadly Sands will Turn Any Living Flesh to Dust in an instant.

column2: Beyond This Barrier is the
column3: Beyond This Barrier is the

column2: LAND OF OZ
column3: LAND OF OZ

column2: But no one can Reach that Beautiful Country because of these Destroying Sands
column3: But no one can Reach that Beautiful Country because of these Destroying Sands

column2: Oh, said Dorothy, when the shaggy man had read the sign aloud; "I've seen this desert before, and it's true no one can live who tries to walk upon the sands."
column3: Oh, said Dorothy, when the shaggy man had read the sign aloud; "I've seen this desert before, and it's true no one can live who tries to walk upon the sands."

column2: Then we musn't try it, answered the shaggy man thoughtfully.
column3: Then we musn't try it, answered the shaggy man thoughtfully.

column2: But as we can't go ahead and there's no use going back, what shall we do next?
column3: But as we can't go ahead and there's no use going back, what shall we do next?

column2: Don't know, said Button-Bright.
column3: Don't know, said Button Bright.

column2: I'm sure I don't know, either, added Dorothy, despondently.
column3: I'm sure I don't know, either, added Dorothy, despondently.

column2: I wish father would come for me, sighed the pretty Rainbow's Daughter, "I would take you all to live upon the rainbow, where you could dance along its rays from morning till night, without a care or worry of any sort.
column3: I wish father would come for me, sighed the pretty Rainbow's Daughter, "I would take you all to live upon the rainbow, where you could dance along its rays from morning till night, without a care or worry of any sort.

column2: But I suppose father's too busy just now to search the world for me."
column3: But I suppose father's too busy just now to search the world for me."

column2: Don't want to dance, said Button-Bright, sitting down wearily upon the soft grass.
column3: Don't want to dance, said Button Bright, sitting down wearily upon the soft grass.

column2: It's very good of you, Polly, said Dorothy; "but there are other things that would suit me better than dancing on rainbows.
column3: It's very good of you, Polly, said Dorothy; "but there are other things that would suit me better than dancing on rainbows.

column2: I'm 'fraid they'd be kind of soft an' squashy under foot, anyhow, although they're so pretty to look at."
column3: I'm 'fraid they'd be kind of soft an' squashy under foot, anyhow, although they're so pretty to look at."

column2: This didn't help to solve the problem, and they all fell silent and looked at one another questioningly.
column3: This didn't help to solve the problem, and they all fell silent and looked at one another questioningly.

column2: Really, I don't know what to do, muttered the shaggy man, gazing hard at Toto; and the little dog wagged his tail and said "Bow-wow!" just as if he could not tell, either, what to do.
column3: Really, I don't know what to do, muttered the shaggy man, gazing hard at Toto; and the little dog wagged his tail and said "Bow wow!" just as if he could not tell, either, what to do.

column2: Button-Bright got a stick and began to dig in the earth, and the others watched him for a while in deep thought.
column3: Button Bright got a stick and began to dig in the earth, and the others watched him for a while in deep thought.

column2: Finally, the shaggy man said:
column3: Finally, the shaggy man said:

column2: It's nearly evening, now; so we may as well sleep in this pretty place and get rested; perhaps by morning we can decide what is best to be done.
column3: It's nearly evening, now; so we may as well sleep in this pretty place and get rested; perhaps by morning we can decide what is best to be done.

column2: There was little chance to make beds for the children, but the leaves of the trees grew thickly and would serve to keep off the night dews, so the shaggy man piled soft grasses in the thickest shade and when it was dark they lay down and slept peacefully until morning.
column3: There was little chance to make beds for the children, but the leaves of the trees grew thickly and would serve to keep off the night dews, so the shaggy man piled soft grasses in the thickest shade and when it was dark they lay down and slept peacefully until morning.

column2: Long after the others were asleep, however, the shaggy man sat in the starlight by the spring, gazing thoughtfully into its bubbling waters. Suddenly he smiled and nodded to himself as if he had found a good thought, after which he, too, laid himself down under a tree and was soon lost in slumber.
column3: Long after the others were asleep, however, the shaggy man sat in the starlight by the spring, gazing thoughtfully into its bubbling waters. Suddenly he smiled and nodded to himself as if he had found a good thought, after which he, too, laid himself down under a tree and was soon lost in slumber.

column2: In the bright morning sunshine, as they ate of the strawberries and sweet juicy pears, Dorothy said:
column3: In the bright morning sunshine, as they ate of the strawberries and sweet juicy pears, Dorothy said:

column2: Polly, can you do any magic?
column3: Polly, can you do any magic?

column2: No dear, answered Polychrome, shaking her dainty head.
column3: No dear, answered Polychrome, shaking her dainty head.

column2: You ought to know SOME magic, being the Rainbow's Daughter, continued Dorothy, earnestly.
column3: You ought to know SOME magic, being the Rainbow's Daughter, continued Dorothy, earnestly.

column2: But we who live on the rainbow among the fleecy clouds have no use for magic, replied Polychrome.
column3: But we who live on the rainbow among the fleecy clouds have no use for magic, replied Polychrome.

column2: What I'd like, said Dorothy, "is to find some way to cross the desert to the Land of Oz and its Emerald City.
column3: What I'd like, said Dorothy, "is to find some way to cross the desert to the Land of Oz and its Emerald City.

column2: I've crossed it already, you know, more than once.
column3: I've crossed it already, you know, more than once.

column2: First a cyclone carried my house over, and some Silver Shoes brought me back again--in half a second.
column3: First a cyclone carried my house over, and some Silver Shoes brought me back again-in half a second.

column2: Then Ozma took me over on her Magic Carpet, and the Nome King's Magic Belt took me home that time.
column3: Then Ozma took me over on her Magic Carpet, and the Nome King's Magic Belt took me home that time.

column2: You see it was magic that did it every time 'cept the first, and we can't 'spect a cyclone to happen along and take us to the Emerald City now."
column3: You see it was magic that did it every time 'cept the first, and we can't 'spect a cyclone to happen along and take us to the Emerald City now."

column2: No indeed, returned Polly, with a shudder, "I hate cyclones, anyway."
column3: No indeed, returned Polly, with a shudder, "I hate cyclones, anyway."

column2: That's why I wanted to find out if you could do any magic, said the little Kansas girl.
column3: That's why I wanted to find out if you could do any magic, said the little Kansas girl.

column2: I'm sure I can't; and I'm sure Button-Bright can't; and the only magic the shaggy man has is the Love Magnet, which won't help us much.
column3: I'm sure I can't; and I'm sure Button Bright can't; and the only magic the shaggy man has is the Love Magnet, which won't help us much.

column2: Don't be too sure of that, my dear, spoke the shaggy man, a smile on his donkey face.
column3: Don't be too sure of that, my dear, spoke the shaggy man, a smile on his donkey face.

column2: I may not be able to do magic myself, but I can call to us a powerful friend who loves me because I own the Love Magnet, and this friend surely will be able to help us.
column3: I may not be able to do magic myself, but I can call to us a powerful friend who loves me because I own the Love Magnet, and this friend surely will be able to help us.

column2: Who is your friend? asked Dorothy.
column3: Who is your friend? asked Dorothy.

column2: Johnny Dooit.
column3: Johnny Dooit.

column2: What can Johnny do?
column3: What can Johnny do?

column2: Anything, answered the shaggy man, with confidence.
column3: Anything, answered the shaggy man, with confidence.

column2: Ask him to come, she exclaimed, eagerly.
column3: Ask him to come, she exclaimed, eagerly.

column2: The shaggy man took the Love Magnet from his pocket and unwrapped the paper that surrounded it.
column3: The shaggy man took the Love Magnet from his pocket and unwrapped the paper that surrounded it.

column2: Holding the charm in the palm of his hand he looked at it steadily and said these words:
column3: Holding the charm in the palm of his hand he looked at it steadily and said these words:

column2: Dear Johnny Dooit, come to me. I need you bad as bad can be.
column3: Dear Johnny Dooit, come to me. I need you bad as bad can be.

column2: Well, here I am, said a cheery little voice; "but you shouldn't say you need me bad, 'cause I'm always, ALWAYS, good."
column3: Well, here I am, said a cheery little voice; "but you shouldn't say you need me bad, 'cause I'm always, ALWAYS, good."

column2: At this they quickly whirled around to find a funny little man sitting on a big copper chest, puffing smoke from a long pipe.
column3: At this they quickly whirled around to find a funny little man sitting on a big copper chest, puffing smoke from a long pipe.

column2: His hair was grey, his whiskers were grey; and these whiskers were so long that he had wound the ends of them around his waist and tied them in a hard knot underneath the leather apron that reached from his chin nearly to his feet, and which was soiled and scratched as if it had been used a long time.
column3: His hair was grey, his whiskers were grey; and these whiskers were so long that he had wound the ends of them around his waist and tied them in a hard knot underneath the leather apron that reached from his chin nearly to his feet, and which was soiled and scratched as if it had been used a long time.

column2: His nose was broad, and stuck up a little; but his eyes were twinkling and merry.
column3: His nose was broad, and stuck up a little; but his eyes were twinkling and merry.

column2: The little man's hands and arms were as hard and tough as the leather in his apron, and Dorothy thought Johnny Dooit looked as if he had done a lot of hard work in his lifetime.
column3: The little man's hands and arms were as hard and tough as the leather in his apron, and Dorothy thought Johnny Dooit looked as if he had done a lot of hard work in his lifetime.

column2: Good morning, Johnny, said the shaggy man.
column3: Good morning, Johnny, said the shaggy man.

column2: Thank you for coming to me so quickly.
column3: Thank you for coming to me so quickly.

column2: I never waste time, said the newcomer, promptly.
column3: I never waste time, said the newcomer, promptly.

column2: But what's happened to you?	But what's happened to you?

column2: Where did you get that donkey head?
column3: Where did you get that donkey head?

column2: Really, I wouldn't have known you at all, Shaggy Man, if I hadn't looked at your feet."
column3: Really, I wouldn't have known you at all, Shaggy Man, if I hadn't looked at your feet."

column2: The shaggy man introduced Johnny Dooit to Dorothy and Toto and Button-Bright and the Rainbow's Daughter, and told him the story of their adventures, adding that they were anxious now to reach the Emerald City in the Land of Oz, where Dorothy had friends who would take care of them and send them safe home again.
column3: The shaggy man introduced Johnny Dooit to Dorothy and Toto and Button Bright and the Rainbow's Daughter, and told him the story of their adventures, adding that they were anxious now to reach the Emerald City in the Land of Oz, where Dorothy had friends who would take care of them and send them safe home again.

column2: But, said he, "we find that we can't cross this desert, which turns all living flesh that touches it into dust; so I have asked you to come and help us."
column3: But, said he, "we find that we can't cross this desert, which turns all living flesh that touches it into dust; so I have asked you to come and help us."

column2: Johnny Dooit puffed his pipe and looked carefully at the dreadful desert in front of them--stretching so far away they could not see its end.
column3: Johnny Dooit puffed his pipe and looked carefully at the dreadful desert in front of them-stretching so far away they could not see its end.

column2: You must ride, he said, briskly.
column3: You must ride, he said, briskly.

column2: What in? asked the shaggy man.
column3: What in? asked the shaggy man.

column2: In a sand-boat, which has runners like a sled and sails like a ship. The wind will blow you swiftly across the desert and the sand cannot touch your flesh to turn it into dust.
column3: In a sand boat, which has runners like a sled and sails like a ship. The wind will blow you swiftly across the desert and the sand cannot touch your flesh to turn it into dust.

column2: Good! cried Dorothy, clapping her hands delightedly.
column3: Good! cried Dorothy, clapping her hands delightedly.

column2: That was the way the Magic Carpet took us across.	That was the way the Magic Carpet took us across.

column2: We didn't have to touch the horrid sand at all."
column3: We didn't have to touch the horrid sand at all."

column2: But where is the sand-boat? asked the shaggy man, looking all around him.
column3: But where is the sand boat? asked the shaggy man, looking all around him.

column2: I'll make you one, said Johnny Dooit.
column3: I'll make you one, said Johnny Dooit.

column2: As he spoke, he knocked the ashes from his pipe and put it in his pocket.
column3: As he spoke, he knocked the ashes from his pipe and put it in his pocket.

column2: Then he unlocked the copper chest and lifted the lid, and Dorothy saw it was full of shining tools of all sorts and shapes.
column3: Then he unlocked the copper chest and lifted the lid, and Dorothy saw it was full of shining tools of all sorts and shapes.

column2: Johnny Dooit moved quickly now--so quickly that they were astonished at the work he was able to accomplish.
column3: Johnny Dooit moved quickly now-so quickly that they were astonished at the work he was able to accomplish.

column2: He had in his chest a tool for everything he wanted to do, and these must have been magic tools because they did their work so fast and so well.
column3: He had in his chest a tool for everything he wanted to do, and these must have been magic tools because they did their work so fast and so well.

column2: The man hummed a little song as he worked, and Dorothy tried to listen to it.
column3: The man hummed a little song as he worked, and Dorothy tried to listen to it.

column2: She thought the words were something like these:
column3: She thought the words were something like these:

column2: The only way to do a thing Is do it when you can, And do it cheerfully, and sing And work and think and plan. The only real unhappy one Is he who dares to shirk; The only really happy one Is he who cares to work.
column3: The only way to do a thing Is do it when you can, And do it cheerfully, and sing And work and think and plan. The only real unhappy one Is he who dares to shirk; The only really happy one Is he who cares to work.

column2: Whatever Johnny Dooit was singing he was certainly doing things, and they all stood by and watched him in amazement.
column3: Whatever Johnny Dooit was singing he was certainly doing things, and they all stood by and watched him in amazement.

column2: He seized an axe and in a couple of chops felled a tree.
column3: He seized an axe and in a couple of chops felled a tree.

column2: Next he took a saw and in a few minutes sawed the tree-trunk into broad, long boards.
column3: Next he took a saw and in a few minutes sawed the tree trunk into broad, long boards.

column2: He then nailed the boards together into the shape of a boat, about twelve feet long and four feet wide.
column3: He then nailed the boards together into the shape of a boat, about twelve feet long and four feet wide.

column2: He cut from another tree a long, slender pole which, when trimmed of its branches and fastened upright in the center of the boat, served as a mast.
column3: He cut from another tree a long, slender pole which, when trimmed of its branches and fastened upright in the center of the boat, served as a mast.

column2: From the chest he drew a coil of rope and a big bundle of canvas, and with these--still humming his song--he rigged up a sail, arranging it so it could be raised or lowered upon the mast.
column3: From the chest he drew a coil of rope and a big bundle of canvas, and with these-still humming his song-he rigged up a sail, arranging it so it could be raised or lowered upon the mast.

column2: Dorothy fairly gasped with wonder to see the thing grow so speedily before her eyes, and both Button-Bright and Polly looked on with the same absorbed interest.
column3: Dorothy fairly gasped with wonder to see the thing grow so speedily before her eyes, and both Button Bright and Polly looked on with the same absorbed interest.

column2: It ought to be painted, said Johnny Dooit, tossing his tools back into the chest, "for that would make it look prettier.
column3: It ought to be painted, said Johnny Dooit, tossing his tools back into the chest, "for that would make it look prettier.

column2: But 'though I can paint it for you in three seconds it would take an hour to dry, and that's a waste of time."
column3: But 'though I can paint it for you in three seconds it would take an hour to dry, and that's a waste of time."

column2: We don't care how it looks, said the shaggy man, "if only it will take us across the desert."
column3: We don't care how it looks, said the shaggy man, "if only it will take us across the desert."

column2: It will do that, declared Johnny Dooit.

column2: All you need worry about is tipping over.	All you need worry about is tipping over.

column2: Did you ever sail a ship?"
column3: Did you ever sail a ship?"

column2: I've seen one sailed, said the shaggy man.

column2: Sail this boat the way you've seen a ship sailed, and you'll be across the sands before you know it."

column2: With this he slammed down the lid of the chest, and the noise made them all wink.
column3: With this he slammed down the lid of the chest, and the noise made them all wink.

column2: While they were winking the workman disappeared, tools and all.

column2: Oh, that's too bad! cried Dorothy; "I wanted to thank Johnny Dooit for all his kindness to us."
